because of better relevance. in my current use case, my documents may be in arabic and they may be in english.
- case 1: if they are in english, then things work fine and ada-2 (or bge-large if we assume best possible model use) does its job well enough to generate descriptive embeddings for qdrant to search through accurately
- case 2: if they are in arabic, then the embeddings are poor and so the search results will be spoiled, meaning my context information for RAG is inaccurate

BM25 (or similar text based search, but as far as ive found it seems the consensus is that BM25 is most optimal in balance) would help both cases:
case 1: BM25 can help enhance the retrieved information for RAG context
case 2: BM25 can help retrieve unspoiled search results, and therefore more accurate RAG context

note: "spoiled" here means that the true relevance of the text is low, regardless of score

content: >  In most cases, you should only use a single collection with payload-based partitioning.

Setting up multitenancy
How many collections should you create? In most cases, you should only use a single collection with payload-based partitioning. This approach is called multitenancy. It is efficient for most of users, but it requires additional configuration. Learn how to set it up

When should you create multiple collections? When you have a limited number of users and you need isolation. This approach is flexible, but it may be more costly, since creating numerous collections may result in resource overhead. Also, you need to ensure that they do not affect each other in any way, including performance-wise.
https://qdrant.tech/documentation/concepts/collections/

content:
> From the docs it says the best practice is to make one collection or one collection per customer - not one collection per entity type. 

Could you please link to where you found this?

I noticed there are no compound indices. From the docs it says the best practice is to make one collection or one collection per customer - not one collection per entity type. This is very abnormal for me as I come from a background of multi collections in noSQL. 

I have 10 different entity types that i am vectorizing and storing datapoints for. My data also is of the format [ clientId, entityId, knowledgeTypeId] - so it's 3 layers of depth. If I were doing a single collection per clientId i would still need a compound index to query by entityId and knowledgeTypeId. 

Is this setup a candidate for multiple collections per client - 1 per entity Type? I may have 1 client with 10 entity types and each entity type may have 100 knowledge types, and for each knowledge type there may be 10 data points. I expect to have clients in the hundreds.

Soo 100 clients * 10 entity / client - 100 knowledge types / entity * 10 data points / knowledge type = 100 collections of 10,000 vectors of 100 types/payload formats. 

What are the best practices in this situation?

content:
Using mmap is the correct approach when having more data than would fit on disk. I don't think it makes much sense to split the data over two collections, especially if you're querying the data together, other than that it might give you a _bit_ more control.

If it's just the payload that is huge, you may consider to only store that on disk (mmap), and keep the rest in memory.

content: Looks like I missed this yesterday, responded to the fresh convo. @uayyagari

Even if you're already aware, repeating this for completeness: The default embedding model is a cross-encoder. This means that if you've question (query) and answer (passage), you should have different embeddings for query and passage. The prefix is actually useful for improving the ranking and retrieval. 

If you want to store query: embeddings to avoid recomputing them, i.e. as a query cache, would recommend storing that separately. Perhaps in a different collection altogether?

And you can always make embeddings which are both query and passage, by using FastEmbed directly, without the prefixes. My best guess is that the recall is about 5-10% worse, depending on the workload etc.
what's your current version?
Probably it might be required to overload the methods and do not put that prefix. However, I don't know what might be the impact on the recall.

Our use case for group search is as follows:
We have a large payload in collection1 mapped to many vectors(embeddings) in collection2.
Now we need a group_search where I can filter on the payload in collection1 and vector search on collection2. Note that 1 payloads maps to many vectors (not the other way around). How do we go about this?

Sorry, one more comment/question on this.  I just looked back at my original post and realized that my working solution is almost identical to my original non-working code snippet EXCEPT that now I have prefixed my metadata keys in the filter with "metadata.{keyname}".  Is that why it didn't work initially?  Is "metadata." prefix required for using those values with filtering?

So I FINALLY have a filter that works!  Oh my, the hours I have wasted trying to figure this out!!  🙂  That is in NO WAY a criticism of Qdrant or Andrey's attempt to assist me earlier, but rather my own "thick" brain!  I have been writing software for 35+ years, but ZERO Python until a few weeks ago.  And definitely no A/I stuff (langchain, vectors, etc.).  So this has been quite the adventure!  Anyway, for anyone (later) that might need this type of metadata filter using Qdrant "as_retriever()" in a Python script, here you go: 

`from qdrant_client.http import models as qmodels

retriever.search_kwargs = dict(
        filter=qmodels.Filter(
            must=[
                qmodels.FieldCondition(
                    key="metadata.tag1",
                    match=qmodels.MatchValue(value=tag1)
                    ),
                qmodels.FieldCondition(
                    key="metadata.tag2",
                    match=qmodels.MatchAny(any=[tag2, "$$$"])
                )
            ]
        )
    )`

Again, "tag1" (above) is the actual key I included in the "metadata" payload when adding my vectors (it is my high-level grouping).  It is ALWAYS set to a specific value, and it must always be included in my search filtering (during a chat).  "tag2" is a second "metadata" item/key, but in some cases my vectors/points may not have a specific value (basically, they are cross-tag2 or "global" points for "tag2" filtering).  In the above example, I am using "$$$" for the tag2 value to indicate "global" (but you could obviously use any text string for this).  So the above filter will give me:

**- All points where metadata.tag1 = {tag1 value} and where metadata.tag2 = {tag2 value OR "$$$"}**
I created a small collection and THOROUGHLY tested all scenarios, and always got the correct responses (based on the tags) -- VERY thankful!

Thanks to all (Andrey, etc.) for a great product and quick assistance on these support questions -- much appreciated!

Hi! You may upsert points with `wait` flag:
https://qdrant.tech/documentation/concepts/points/#awaiting-result
This flag enables waiting while point is ready for search/recommendation. By default it's false, point may not be ready for search/recommendation after calling `upsert`. Also for distrubuted systems you can read about write ordering
https://qdrant.tech/documentation/guides/distributed_deployment/#write-ordering

If you want to free up space there, you'd need to delete one of your existing snapshots https://qdrant.tech/documentation/concepts/snapshots/#delete-snapshot
